replication_study.hypothesis: Among low-caste households (locaste==1), residing in a low-caste dominated village (locaste_land_v==1) is associated with higher agricultural income per acre (raw_inc_per_acre) compared to residing in an upper-caste dominated village (locaste_land_v==0), controlling for household literacy and land owned, with state-by-caste fixed effects, and clustering standard errors at the village level.

data_plan.source_type: Household/village survey-derived dataset (constructed for replication; aligned with World Bank LSMS UP–Bihar design).
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Low-caste households sample with coverage across multiple states (stcode 1–17); subset analysis for Uttar Pradesh and Bihar (stcode in {2,15}).
data_plan.access_details: Provided in the repository under data/original/12/0112_gpt5/replication_data; no additional access restrictions indicated.

qualification.explanation: This dataset includes all variables needed to estimate the focal specification and tests the same mechanism in an independent sample of low-caste households. It enables replication of the core OLS model with village-clustered standard errors and state-by-caste fixed effects.
qualification.similarity_to_original: The original study used the World Bank LSMS (UP–Bihar) 1997–1998 village and household questionnaires with 2,250 households across 120 villages and focused on agricultural income and yields with indicators for low-caste dominated villages and extensive controls (post_registration.json; original_paper.pdf summary). The replication dataset provides the same operational variables: raw_inc_per_acre (outcome), locaste_land_v (key predictor), literate_hh and land_owned (controls), stcode and caste for fixed effects, and vill_id for clustering (analysis_data.dta columns; anderson_2011_replication_data_analysis.do shows identical model inputs).
qualification.deviation_from_original: Original analyses centered on Uttar Pradesh and Bihar (post_registration.json; original_paper.pdf summary). The replication dataset spans multiple states (stcode Min=1, Max=17; get_dataset_variable_summary), with 2,610 observations (get_dataset_shape), exceeding the original sample size (2,250). While our main specification uses the full replication sample, we also run a subset for UP and Bihar (stcode in {2,15}) to align with the original focus (anderson_2011_replication_data_analysis.do).

data_plan.notes: Variables present: ['id2','stcode','caste','vill_id','locaste','literate_hh','land_owned','net_inc_per_acre','raw_inc_per_acre','locaste_land_v']. locaste is constant at 1 (replication sample is low-caste only). locaste_land_v is binary {0,1}. caste has high cardinality (up to 532); stcode ranges 1–17. OLS will include C(stcode)*C(caste), which is computationally heavier but faithful to the Stata specification. No missing values observed in inspected variables.

steps: Run OLS with village-clustered SE: raw_inc_per_acre ~ literate_hh + land_owned + locaste_land_v + C(stcode)*C(caste).
Record coefficient, SE, p-value for locaste_land_v. Save model summaries.
Run exploratory OLS replacing outcome with net_inc_per_acre.
Run UP/Bihar subset (stcode in {2,15}) to mirror original state focus and estimate the same OLS.
Compare the replication estimates on locaste_land_v against the original coefficient (566.5, SE 209; initial_details.txt) and discuss consistency in sign, magnitude, and significance.
planned_method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) with village-clustered robust standard errors; categorical fixed effects and interactions via C(stcode)*C(caste).
planned_method.control_variables: literate_hh (household literacy indicator), land_owned (land owned), state-by-caste interactions via C(stcode)*C(caste).
planned_method.tools_software: Python 3.10; pandas for data IO; statsmodels for OLS with clustered SE; numpy for utilities.

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient on locaste_land_v in OLS regression of income per acre.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: t-test (two-sided) on the locaste_land_v coefficient with village-clustered SE.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion (default in statsmodels given the specified columns).
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Single primary outcome; exploratory outcome (net_inc_per_acre) reported without multiplicity adjustment.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Primary: Sign and statistical significance (p<0.05, two-sided) of locaste_land_v; magnitude compared to the original (566.5 with SE 209).

files.replication_data/anderson_2011_replicati: Original Stata analysis by Nathaniel Porter. It loads analysis_data.dta and runs OLS: regress raw_inc_per_acre literate_hh land_owned locaste_land_v stcode##caste, vce(cluster vill_id). It also runs a net income per acre model and a UP/Bihar subset. Outputs etable summaries.
files.anderson_2011_replication_data_analysis_: Python translation that reads /app/data/analysis_data.dta and runs three OLS models using statsmodels with cluster-robust SE by vill_id: (1) full sample raw_inc_per_acre; (2) exploratory net_inc_per_acre; (3) UP/Bihar subset raw_inc_per_acre (stcode in {2,15}). It writes CSV and text summaries to /app/data.

codebase.notes: Environment is read-only during planning, so the Python file could not be written. At execution time, create /app/data/anderson_2011_replication_data_analysis__py.py with the provided translation. The script uses formula: outcome ~ literate_hh + land_owned + locaste_land_v + C(stcode)*C(caste), cov_type='cluster' with groups=vill_id. Ensure analysis_data.dta is copied to /app/data before running. No GPU or non-Python dependencies required.

Create /app/data/anderson_2011_replication_data_analysis__py.py with the translated code below.
Outputs: /app/data/anderson_2011_results.csv and /app/data/anderson_2011_results.txt containing model summaries and the key coefficient on locaste_land_v.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare the coefficient on locaste_land_v and its cluster-robust SE (and p-value) to the original reported coefficient (566.5; SE 209; initial_details.txt). Evaluate sign (positive), magnitude similarity, and statistical significance at 5%.
